title.narrative: OUTPUT 2.3 Water, Sanitation, and Hygiene (WASH) COMMUNITY & INSTITUTIONS

description.narrative: 2.3 More vulnerable populations benefit from sustainable safe water supply and basic sanitation services at community and institutional levels, which contributes to Climate Change, Disaster Risks And Envionmental Degradation, Reducing Child Poverty, Safe And Equitable Water, Sanitation And Hygiene Services And Practices, Water, Sanitation And Hygiene Systems And Empowerment Of Communities. UNICEF aims to achieve this through Advocacy And Public Engagement, Developing And Leveraging Resources And Partnerships, Evaluations, Research And Data, Operational Support To Programme Delivery, Systems Strengthening And Institution Building, Systems Strengthening To Leave No One Behind. This contributes to the following Country Programme result: By 2022, children, adolescents and women, especially the most vulnerable, have improved access to equitable use of safe drinking water, sanitation, hygiene practices and healthy environments

condition.narrative: Should contribute directly to results for children as outlined in the UNDAF, national results and/or UNICEF Strategic Plan and within the scope defined in the CPD, CPAP, OMP or other agreed upon programme documents

title.narrative: 2.3 More vulnerable populations benefit from sustainable safe water supply and basic sanitation services at community andinstitutional levels

description.narrative: Under the development and resilient portfolio, total of 1,619,658 vulnerable directly benefitted from improved access to a sustainable drinking water source. Similarly, for basic sanitation services total of 808,060 vulnerable people out of the target of 1,868,785 benefited from the rehabilitation of wastewater treatment systems with UNICEF technical and financial support, and rehabilitation of WASH facilities to 96 Health care facilities which are in affected locations by Cholera and COVID-19 risks. Moreover, WASH programme conducted a technical verification exercise for 800 HFs which are been assessed, reviewed and prepared process for rehabilitation, in parallel completed rehabilitation of 96 HFs. | Status:Partially met | As-of Date:13/01/2022
